TabPFN: One Model to Rule Them All?

QiongÂ Zhang label=e1]qiong.zhang@ruc.edu.cn [ â€ƒâ€ƒ Yan ShuoÂ Tanlabel=e2]yanshuo@nus.edu.sg [ â€ƒâ€ƒ QinglongÂ Tianlabel=e3]qinglong.tian@uwaterloo.ca [ â€ƒâ€ƒ PengfeiÂ Lilabel=e4]pengfei.li@uwaterloo.ca [ Qiong Zhang is Assistant Professor, Institute of Statistics & Big Data, Renmin University of China, Chinapresep=Â ]e1. Yan Shuo Tan is Assistant Professor, Department of Statistics & Data Science, National University of Singapore, Singaporepresep=Â ]e2. Qinglong Tian is Assistant Professor, Department of Statistics & Actuarial Science, University or Waterloo, Canadapresep=Â ]e3. Pengfei Li is Professor, Department of Statistics & Actuarial Science, University or Waterloo, Canadapresep=Â ]e4.
Abstract

Hollmann et al. (Nature 637 (2025) 319â€“326) recently introduced TabPFN, a transformer-based deep learning model for regression and classification on tabular data, which they claim â€œoutperforms all previous methods on datasets with up to 10,000 samples by a wide margin, using substantially less training time.â€ Furthermore, they have called TabPFN a â€œfoundation modelâ€ for tabular data, as it can support â€œdata generation, density estimation, learning reusable embeddings and fine-tuningâ€. If these statements are well-supported, TabPFN may have the potential to supersede existing modeling approaches on a wide range of statistical tasks, mirroring a similar revolution in other areas of artificial intelligence that began with the advent of large language models. In this paper, we provide a tailored explanation of how TabPFN works for a statistics audience, by emphasizing its interpretation as approximate Bayesian inference. We also provide more evidence of TabPFNâ€™s â€œfoundation modelâ€ capabilities: We show that an out-of-the-box application of TabPFN vastly outperforms specialized state-of-the-art methods for semi-supervised parameter estimation, prediction under covariate shift, and heterogeneous treatment effect estimation. We further show that TabPFN can outperform LASSO at sparse regression and can break a robustness-efficiency trade-off in classification. All experiments can be reproduced using the code provided at https://github.com/qinglong-tian/tabpfn_study.

1 Introduction

Deep learning has achieved remarkable success in modeling unstructured data types such as text and images. However, for tabular dataâ€”arguably the most prevalent and consequential data type across scienceâ€”ensemble tree methods have remained the gold standard predictive modeling strategy, consistently outperforming even deep learning on benchmark datasetsÂ [9, 13, 29, 17]. This long-held wisdom has now been challenged by Hollmann etÂ al. [20], who introduced a deep learning method for tabular data, called TabPFN, which they claimed â€œoutperforms all previous methods on datasets with up to 10,000 samples by a wide margin, using substantially less training time.â€ As evidence, they showed that TabPFN significantly outperforms random forests, XGBoost, LightGBM, and CatBoost on 50505050+ benchmark classification and regression datasets.

Beyond its impressive predictive accuracy, TabPFN is claimed to be robust to outliers and missing data, and automatically estimates predictive distributions, thereby providing uncertainty quantification. Furthermore, it can support â€œdata generation, density estimation, learning reusable embeddings and fine-tuningâ€. Because of this wide range of capabilities, Hollmann etÂ al. [20] call TabPFN a â€œtabular foundation modelâ€Â [39], appropriating a term that has been used to describe the transformative role played by large language models (LLMs)Â [6] in natural language processing. TabPFN shares other similarities with LLMs: It makes use of the same type of deep learning architecture (transformers)Â [40] and the same learning paradigm (in-context learning)Â [7], which differs fundamentally from traditional statistical and machine learning approaches.

Given TabPFNâ€™s promising capabilities, the goal of this paper is twofold.

  • â€¢

    First, we aim to provide an explanation of how TabPFN works that is tailored to a statistics audience (Section 2).

  • â€¢

    Second, and more importantly, we aim to explore the significance of TabPFN to the field of statistics.

Towards the second goal, we demonstrate the utility of TabPFN in handling three currently researched estimation problems, namely semi-supervised parameter estimation (Section 3.1), prediction under covariate shift (Section 3.3), and heterogeneous treatment effects estimation (Section 3.2). For each problem, we compare a simple out-of-the-box application of TabPFN to a â€œstate-of-the-artâ€ method proposed by a selected paper published recently in a top statistics journal. Using the same simulation set-up described by the paper, we show that TabPFN achieves significantly better estimation accuracy than the comparator method.

Apart from examining the performance of TabPFN on specialized estimation tasks, we also examine how it adapts to different types of structure in regression and classification problems. We observe that it outperforms parametric methods (LASSO and linear discriminant analysis) when the model is correctly specified, as well as local averaging and smoothing methods when the model is misspecified (such as via label noise in classification). We discuss these and other discoveries regarding the inductive biases of TabPFN in Section 4.

It is not the point of our paper, however, to suggest that TabPFN is a perfect model. Rather, our argument is that the approach it takesâ€”â€œin-context learningâ€ using a â€œfoundation modelâ€â€”has the potential to supersede existing modeling approaches on a wide range of statistical tasks, mirroring a similar revolution in other areas of artificial intelligence that began with the advent of large language models (LLMs). We define these key terms and discuss them further in Section 5. We also discuss opportunities for statisticians to influence the fieldâ€™s development.

2 An overview of TabPFN

TabPFN makes use of in-context learning (ICL), which is a new learning paradigm that differs from the standard statistical learning approach to regression and classification and which has gathered significant interest in the machine learning community. The meaning of ICL has changed over time. In TabPFN, ICL takes the form of approximate Bayesian inference; we elaborate on this perspective below and defer a discussion on the historical development of ICL to SectionÂ 5.

The first key idea of TabPFN is to approximate posterior predictive distributions (PPD) using a transformer model, which is the same deep learning architecture that powers LLMs. More precisely, let Î Î \Piroman_Î  denote the space of joint distributions on covariate-label pairs (X,Y)ğ‘‹ğ‘Œ(X,Y)( italic_X , italic_Y ) and let nğ‘›nitalic_n be a fixed sample size. The TabPFN transformer Mğ‘€Mitalic_M is trained to approximate the mapping (ğ’Ÿ,x)â†¦pâ¢(y|x,ğ’Ÿ)maps-toğ’Ÿğ‘¥ğ‘conditionalğ‘¦ğ‘¥ğ’Ÿ(\mathcal{D},x)\mapsto p(y|x,\mathcal{D})( caligraphic_D , italic_x ) â†¦ italic_p ( italic_y | italic_x , caligraphic_D ). MÃ¼ller etÂ al. [26], who developed this approach, called the resulting model a prior-fitted network (PFN).

Approximating the PPD of a Bayesian regression or classification model is far from a new idea. Indeed, the popular Bayesian Additive Regression Trees (BART) algorithm does precisely this via Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) [11]. The novelty of the PFN approach is that while previous approaches (MCMC, variational inference, likelihood-free inference, etc.) attempt to approximate the map xâ†¦pâ¢(y|x,ğ’Ÿ)maps-toğ‘¥ğ‘conditionalğ‘¦ğ‘¥ğ’Ÿx\mapsto p(y|x,\mathcal{D})italic_x â†¦ italic_p ( italic_y | italic_x , caligraphic_D ) for a fixed training dataset ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D, PFN tries to approximate the map jointly over xğ‘¥xitalic_x and ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D. It has the computational benefit of amortizing computation, which is the basis of the â€œsubstantially less training timeâ€ claim by Hollmann etÂ al. [20] regarding TabPFN.111Similar ideas have been explored in the variational inference community under the name of Neural Processes (NP) [16]. Both the NP and PFN approaches use a â€œmeta-learningâ€ perspective to approximate the PPD, but they differ in their implementation choices. NPs employ an encoder-decoder architecture with a parametric distribution over the latent variable zğ‘§zitalic_z, naturally lending itself to variational inference. PFNs, on the other hand, adopt a transformer architecture that avoids explicit distributional assumptions in its internal representations. As a result, their training objectives differ slightly: NPs explicitly optimize a variational lower bound, while PFNs frame learning as a direct optimization problem. Such an approximation may also produce statistical benefits via implicit regularization that are yet to be fully understood.

The second key idea of TabPFN is its choice of prior on the space of joint distribution Î Î \Piroman_Î . The large number of parameters of a transformer model (â‰ˆ\approxâ‰ˆ 7M in the case of TabPFN) means that it could potentially approximate PPDs defined in terms of complicated priors. TabPFN chooses to define its prior in terms of structural causal models (SCMs) [30]. An SCM defines a directed acyclic graph ğ’¢ğ’¢\mathcal{G}caligraphic_G whose nodes represent variables Z1,â€¦,Zpsubscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘Z_{1},\ldots,Z_{p}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and whose edges represent causal relationships. Specifically, each variable Zksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜Z_{k}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is defined via the equation Zk=fkâ¢(ZPAğ’¢â¡(k),Îµk)subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘“ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘subscriptPAğ’¢ğ‘˜subscriptğœ€ğ‘˜Z_{k}=f_{k}(Z_{\operatorname{PA}_{\mathcal{G}}(k)},\varepsilon_{k})italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_PA start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), where fksubscriptğ‘“ğ‘˜f_{k}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a deterministic function, PAğ’¢â¡(k)subscriptPAğ’¢ğ‘˜\operatorname{PA}_{\mathcal{G}}(k)roman_PA start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_k ) denotes the parents of Zksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜Z_{k}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and Îµ1,â€¦,Îµpsubscriptğœ€1â€¦subscriptğœ€ğ‘\varepsilon_{1},\ldots,\varepsilon_{p}italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are independent â€œexogenousâ€ random variables. SCMs have long been used to model causal inference from observational data, in which case f1,â€¦,fpsubscriptğ‘“1â€¦subscriptğ‘“ğ‘f_{1},\ldots,f_{p}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are usually defined to be linear functions. These two key ideas cohere to provide an efficient training strategy for TabPFN. 3 Case studies

3.1 Case study I: parameter estimation in a semi-supervised setting

3.1.1 Problem and motivation.

In regression and classification problems, labeled data are often scarce or costly to obtain, while unlabeled data are typically more abundant. This abundance arises because unlabeled data (e.g.,Â medical images, sensor readings, or customer transactions) are often generated organically during routine operations, whereas the corresponding labels (e.g.,Â diagnoses, system states, or purchase intentions) require expert annotation or time-consuming measurement. Semi-supervised learning methods (SSL)Â [45] attempt to improve the efficiency of statistical analyses on the labeled data by leveraging information contained in unlabeled data, usually under the assumption that both sets of data share the same data-generating distribution.

We consider the problem of parameter estimation in an SSL setting. To formalize this, let Xâˆˆâ„pğ‘‹superscriptâ„ğ‘X\in{\mathbb{R}}^{p}italic_X âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT denote the feature vector and Yâˆˆâ„ğ‘Œâ„Y\in{\mathbb{R}}italic_Y âˆˆ blackboard_R the response variable. We observe:

    Song, Lin and Zhou [37] (SLZ) proposed a method that makes a projection-based correction to the ERM loss (2). 3.1.4 Results.

Representative results of our experiments are shown in FigureÂ 1, with the complete set of results deferred to AppendixÂ A. The top left, top right, and bottom left panels show MSE with respect to linear, logistic, and quantile regression respectively when p=5ğ‘5p=5italic_p = 5, with various combinations of (n,m)ğ‘›ğ‘š(n,m)( italic_n , italic_m ). In the bottom right panel, we show how the results for logistic regression vary with pğ‘pitalic_p, observing that SLZ is only able to outperform the TabPFN approaches when p=4ğ‘4p=4italic_p = 4. In general, we observe that TabPFN-I and TabPFN-D significantly outperform SLZ in terms of MSE. We also decompose MSE into squared bias (shaded bar) and variance (solid bar) for the four methods and observe that while TabPFN-I has larger bias than TabPFN-D (as well as the other two methods), it has significantly smaller variance, which leads to smaller MSE.

3.2 Case study II: heterogeneous treatment effects estimation

3.2.1 Problem and motivation.

While researchers were previously satisfied with estimating the average effect of a treatmentâ€“such as a drug, social intervention, or economic policyâ€“across a population of interest, there has been rising interest in estimating heterogeneous treatment effects (HTE), that is, how different groups of individuals might benefit differentially from the same treatment. Accurate estimation of HTE can allow for personalized treatments, which may lead to better outcomes.

HTE is usually quantified via the Neymanâ€“Rubin potential outcomes frameworkÂ [35]. Foster and Syrgkanis [14] advocated for either the R-Learner or DR-Learner as, unlike the S-, T- and X-Learners, they satisfy Neyman orthogonality, which result in theoretically faster estimation rates so long as the base learners used to estimate the nuisance parameters (e.g. eâ¢(x)ğ‘’ğ‘¥e(x)italic_e ( italic_x ) and mâ¢(x)ğ‘šğ‘¥m(x)italic_m ( italic_x )) satisfy certain convergence properties. In their numerical experiments, they used Wang etÂ al. [42]â€™s AutoML algorithm555AutoML uses cross-validation and a smart exploration strategy to select from a collection of the most popular machine learning models and to tune their hyperparameters. as the base learner in the meta-leaner strategies detailed above, and showed that the R-Learner or DR-Learner indeed achieved better performance.

3.2.3 Experimental design.

We repeat Foster and Syrgkanis [14]â€™s experiments, but add TabPFN as a choice of base learner. We compare the five meta-learner strategies detailed above, together with an â€œoracleâ€ comprising the R-Learner fitted with the true nuisance functions mâ¢(x)ğ‘šğ‘¥m(x)italic_m ( italic_x ) and eâ¢(x)ğ‘’ğ‘¥e(x)italic_e ( italic_x ). Note that the optimization problemÂ (3) for the R-Learner is solved via weighted least squares. Since TabPFN currently does not support weighted loss minimization, this means that it cannot be used as a base learner for both the R-Learner and oracle methods. This results in 10 total estimators (2222 base learners Ã— 6666 methods â€“ 2222 exclusions). Throughout our analysis, we identify each estimator by its method followed by the base learner in parentheses (e.g., â€˜S-Learner (TabPFN)â€™).

3.2.4 Results.

We display the results for Setup A and E in FigureÂ 2 and defer the complete set of experimental results to TableÂ 4 in AppendixÂ B. Most strikingly, across all experimental settings, using TabPFN as the base learner in a meta-learner strategy greatly improves upon its AutoML counterpart. Second, despite its lack of Neyman orthogonality or double robustness, S-Learner (TabPFN) achieves the best accuracy in most settings and is among the top two performers in almost all settings. Our results stand in contrast to those of Foster and Syrgkanis [14] and the rest of the current HTE literature, which has tended to de-emphasize the role played by the base learner because the error it accrues when estimating the nuisance parameters becomes second-order for the R- and DR-Learners under what they consider to be relatively mild conditions. The superior performance of S-Learner (TabPFN) shows that this asymptotic regime is not attained, even under relatively simple simulation settings, and that the choice of base learner can be equally important as the choice of metalearner framework. Indeed, the superior regularization of TabPFN compared to other regression estimators may have a special synergy with the S-Learner strategy, resulting in its superior accuracy, especially in low sample size and signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) settings.

3.3 Case study III: prediction under covariate shift

3.3.1 Problem and motivation.

In regression and classification problems, covariate shift refers to the scenario where the marginal covariate distribution pâ¢(x)ğ‘ğ‘¥p(x)italic_p ( italic_x ) differs between training and test datasets, while the predictive distribution pâ¢(y|x)ğ‘conditionalğ‘¦ğ‘¥p(y|x)italic_p ( italic_y | italic_x ) remains the same. This distributional mismatch frequently arises in real-world applicationsâ€”for instance, due to outdated training data or sampling biases between datasets. Since covariate shift can substantially degrade model performance, it has become an active area of researchÂ [32, 31, 43].

More precisely, we observe a training dataset ğ’Ÿssubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘ {\mathcal{D}}_{s}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT comprising nğ‘›nitalic_n IID observations from a source distribution psâ¢(x)â¢pâ¢(y|x)subscriptğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘¥ğ‘conditionalğ‘¦ğ‘¥p_{s}(x)p(y|x)italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) italic_p ( italic_y | italic_x ) and wish to predict the responses on a test dataset ğ’Ÿtsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡{\mathcal{D}}_{t}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT comprising mğ‘šmitalic_m IID observations from the target distribution ptâ¢(x)â¢pâ¢(y|x)subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘¥ğ‘conditionalğ‘¦ğ‘¥p_{t}(x)p(y|x)italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) italic_p ( italic_y | italic_x ), with accuracy evaluated via prediction MSE. Furthermore, psâ¢(x)subscriptğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘¥p_{s}(x)italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) and ptâ¢(x)subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘¥p_{t}(x)italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) are usually unknown and have to be estimated from data.

3.3.2 State-of-the-art.

Classical approaches to address covariate shift make use of importance weighting techniques. More recently, the problem has been studied under the assumption that the regression function fâ¢(x)=ğ”¼â¢(Y|X=x)ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ”¼conditionalğ‘Œğ‘‹ğ‘¥f(x)={\mathbb{E}}(Y|X=x)italic_f ( italic_x ) = blackboard_E ( italic_Y | italic_X = italic_x ) has bounded norm in a reproducing kernel Hilbert space, in which case kernel ridge regression (KRR) with a carefully tuned regularization parameter Î»ğœ†\lambdaitalic_Î» was shown to achieve optimal rates, whereas a naÃ¯ve, unadjusted estimator is suboptimalÂ [25]. Wang [41] introduced a method based on â€œpseudo-labelingâ€ (PL) for selecting Î»ğœ†\lambdaitalic_Î», claiming that it improves upon Ma, Pathak and Wainwright [25]â€™s work by relaxing certain distributional assumptions. Specifically, PL fits KRR on the first half of ğ’Ÿssubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘ {\mathcal{D}}_{s}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and uses the fitted model to impute labels for an auxiliary unlabeled dataset ğ’Ÿ~tsubscript~ğ’Ÿğ‘¡\widetilde{{\mathcal{D}}}_{t}over~ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT drawn from ptâ¢(x)subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘¥p_{t}(x)italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ). 4 TabPFN inductive biases

A classical statistical method makes explicit assumptions about how data is generated, with its prediction performance suffering degradation when those assumptions do not hold. Conversely, when the data contains structure that is not exploited by the method, such as when applying smoothing splines to data generated from a linear model, the prediction performance of the method can be relatively inefficient. Machine learning methods, such as tree-based ensembles and neural networks, are algorithmically defined, which means that these assumptions are implicit rather than explicit. These implicit assumptions are referred to as the methodâ€™s inductive bias. Uncovering the inductive biases of ML methods is an active and important area of research, as it tells us when we can expect a given method to do well and when it might perform poorly.

In this section, we attempt to investigate TabPFNâ€™s inductive biases via a collection of numerical experiments. Our takeaways are that

  • â€¢

    In low dimensions, TabPFN seems similar to Gaussian process regression in its ability to adapt flexibly to any functional form, but differs notably in its manner of extrapolation, ease of fitting step functions, and conservativeness at fitting quickly-varying functions.

  • â€¢

    TabPFN can outperform LASSO at high sparsity and low SNR settings by avoiding excessive shrinkage of relevant feature coefficients. On the other hand, it generally performs even worse than LASSO for dense linear regression for â‰¥20absent20\geq 20â‰¥ 20 features.

  • â€¢

    TabPFN is able to break a robustness-efficiency trade-off in classification: It is simultaneously robust to label noise (a type of model misspecification), while being as efficient as linear discriminant analysis (LDA) when it is correctly specified.

4.1 Interpolation and extrapolation

In our first experiment, we examine how TabPFN interpolates and extrapolates from observed data. For simplicity, we demonstrate this in a univariate setting and with respect to four simple functional forms: (i) a linear function, (ii) a quadratic function, (iii) a step function, and (iv) a piecewise linear function. The results for n=31ğ‘›31n=31italic_n = 31 training data points are shown in Figure 4, with the results for n=11ğ‘›11n=11italic_n = 11 and experimental details deferred to AppendixÂ D. For comparison, we also show the results obtained using Gaussian process regression (GPR) with both kernel and noise variance parameters tuned using marginal likelihood. We observe that in all cases, TabPFN fits a smoothly-varying curve that broadly resembles the GPR curve within the interpolation region. The notable differences are:

  • â€¢

    Unlike GPR, TabPFN seems not to suffer from the Gibbs phenomenon (fluctuations at the point of discontinuity of a step function).

  • â€¢

    TabPFN extrapolates at roughly the same level of the last observed response, whereas GPR quickly asymptotes to zero (the GPR prior mean).

  • â€¢

    TabPFN is more conservative than GPR at fitting a quickly-varying function. GPR is able to roughly approximate the piecewise-linear function with n=11ğ‘›11n=11italic_n = 11, whereas TabPFN still outputs a constant model.

  • â€¢

    TabPFN has a more diffuse conditional predictive distribution pâ¢(y|x)ğ‘conditionalğ‘¦ğ‘¥p(y|x)italic_p ( italic_y | italic_x ) compared to GPR, especially away from the interpolation region.

4.2 Comparison with LASSO regression

In our second experiment, we perform a head-to-head comparison between TabPFN and LASSO when applied to sparse linear regression. The main point is to demonstrate that while TabPFN is seemingly flexible enough to adapt to any type of functional structure, it can nevertheless sometimes recognize and adapt to situations when the dataset contains additional parametric structure, even competing favorably with methods designed specifically to handle that structure. In addition to this, we also observe some other unexpected results.

4.2.1 Experimental design.

We broadly follow the experimental design ofÂ Hastie, Tibshirani and Tibshirani [18]. We generate Y=XâŠ¤â¢Î²âˆ—+Ïµğ‘Œsuperscriptğ‘‹topsuperscriptğ›½italic-ÏµY=X^{\top}\beta^{*}+\epsilonitalic_Y = italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î² start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_Ïµ, with Î²âˆ—âˆˆâ„psuperscriptğ›½superscriptâ„ğ‘\beta^{*}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{p}italic_Î² start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT having sparsity sğ‘ sitalic_s (i.e.,Â sğ‘ sitalic_s entries are 1111 and the rest are 00). We consider two types of Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²:

  • â€¢

    Beta-type I: Î²âˆ—superscriptğ›½\beta^{*}italic_Î² start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has sğ‘ sitalic_s components equal to 1111, spaced approximately evenly across the pğ‘pitalic_p indices, and the rest equal to 00;

  • â€¢

    Beta-type II: Î²âˆ—superscriptğ›½\beta^{*}italic_Î² start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has its first sğ‘ sitalic_s components equal to 1111, and the rest equal to 00.

4.2.2 Prediction performance comparison.

In Figure 5, we plot the relative test MSE (averaged over 300300300300 repetitions) of TabPFN to that of LASSO across all experimental settings. We observe that TabPFN generally outperforms LASSO when either the SNR is low or sparsity level is high (i.e. small sğ‘ sitalic_s). However, the performance of TabPFN can be much worse than LASSO for low sparsity (i.e. large sğ‘ sitalic_s) settings, especially when SNR is high. Given that LASSO itself is not especially suited to dense linear regression, this also reveals that TabPFN has a severe inductive bias against dense linear structure.666In other unreported experiments, we also observed that TabPFN performs poorly more generally whenever the regression function depends on a relatively large number of features.

4.2.3 How linear is the TabPFN model?

To further assess and explain these relative performance differences, we wish to inspect the prediction surface of a fitted TabPFN model. To do this, we make use of Accumulated Local Effects (ALE) plots, which summarize the dependence of the model on each individual feature [2].777ALE plots avoid both the confounding associated with conditional dependence plots and the out-of-sample instability associated with marginal dependence plots. Figure 17 exhibits the results when the features are orthogonal. We observe that for moderate to high SNR (â‰¥1.22absent1.22\geq 1.22â‰¥ 1.22), almost all ALE plots of relevant features are roughly linear. In addition, when n=500ğ‘›500n=500italic_n = 500, the ALE plots for the irrelevant features display much less variation, which suggests that the TabPFN model is indeed well-approximated by a low-dimensional linear surface. For smaller SNR, the ALE plots are generally nonlinear and are not shown.

To further quantify the faithfulness of the linear approximation in the settings identified above (n=500ğ‘›500n=500italic_n = 500, SNRâ‰¥1.22SNR1.22\text{SNR}\geq 1.22SNR â‰¥ 1.22), we fit an ordinary least squares model to the TabPFN predicted values using only the relevant features. As shown in the Table 2, the resulting test set R2superscriptğ‘…2R^{2}italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT values are at least 0.950.950.950.95. Furthermore, we can treat the regression coefficients of the linear approximation as estimates of the true regression coefficients. The bias and variance of these estimates are also shown in Table 2. For high to moderate sparsity, we observe that the TabPFN coefficients have smaller bias compared to the LASSO coefficients. Although we report squared bias, we note that all bias values are negative. We thus observe that TabPFN is able to avoid the well-known tendency of LASSO to bias its estimates via shrinkage.

4.3 Robustness-efficiency trade-offs in classification

In our last experiment, we examine the classification performance of TabPFN in the presence of label noise, that is, when the observed labels Y~1,Y~2,â€¦,Y~nsubscript~ğ‘Œ1subscript~ğ‘Œ2â€¦subscript~ğ‘Œğ‘›\tilde{Y}_{1},\tilde{Y}_{2},\ldots,\tilde{Y}_{n}over~ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , over~ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , over~ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in our training set are corrupted from their true values Y1,Y2,â€¦,Ynsubscriptğ‘Œ1subscriptğ‘Œ2â€¦subscriptğ‘Œğ‘›Y_{1},Y_{2},\ldots,Y_{n}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, such as by coding errors. For simplicity, we consider homogeneous noise in a binary class setting:

This problem is especially interesting when the conditional distribution of the true label, pâ¢(Y|X=x)ğ‘conditionalğ‘Œğ‘‹ğ‘¥p(Y|X=x)italic_p ( italic_Y | italic_X = italic_x ), has a simple parametric form. In comparison, Cannings, Fan and Samworth [8] proved that kğ‘˜kitalic_k-nearest neighbors (kğ‘˜kitalic_kNN) and kernelized support vector machines (SVM) can be robust to label noise. However, these methods, which are based on local averaging, pay a price in terms of being less efficient when the labels are noise free.

We show that TabPFN is able to break this robustness-efficiency trade-off. On the one hand, it remains consistent in the presence of label noise. On the other hand, it is more efficient than kğ‘˜kitalic_kNN, SVM and even LDA across all simulation settings, including when there is no label noise.

Details such as hyper-parameter selection are deferred to AppendixÂ F. This process is repeated 1000 times, with FigureÂ 6 showing the average excess risk across repetitions.

4.3.2 Prediction performance comparison.

Under both generative models, TabPFN (clean) performs as well as the optimal Bayes classifier when the training set size is bigger than 2222K. TabPFN (noisy) shows slightly worse performance than its clean-data counterpart but demonstrates exceptional robustness to label noise in all cases while maintaining high accuracy. Even with noise levels as high as Ï=0.3ğœŒ0.3\rho=0.3italic_Ï = 0.3, TabPFN (noisy) nearly matches the optimal classifier given a sufficiently large training set (â‰¥5absent5\geq 5â‰¥ 5K samples). LDA exhibits no robustness under M1 and performs poorly under M2 due to the nonlinear Bayes decision boundary. While the kğ‘˜kitalic_k-NN classifier shows some consistencyâ€”particularly under M2 with low noise levelsâ€”it is less robust than TabPFN in other scenarios. Moreover, FigureÂ 7 demonstrates that TabPFN remains robust even at Ï=0.4ğœŒ0.4\rho=0.4italic_Ï = 0.4. Interestingly, we notice that there is a significant performance gap between Ï=0.3ğœŒ0.3\rho=0.3italic_Ï = 0.3 and Ï=0.4ğœŒ0.4\rho=0.4italic_Ï = 0.4 for small training set sizes.

5 Discussion

5.1 Foundation models

In 2021, Bommasani etÂ al. [6] coined the term â€œfoundation modelâ€ to refer to â€œany model that is trained on broad data (generally using self-supervision at scale) that can be adapted (e.g., fine-tuned) to a wide range of downstream tasksâ€. They also noted a paradigm shift in artificial intelligence which de-prioritized the development of task-specific models in favor of building these foundation models, with LLMs being the most prominent examples. Until recently, the modality of tabular data has resisted this trend, but the tide may be turning. Hollmann etÂ al. [20] provided a proof-of-concept that, in addition to regression and classification, TabPFN can support â€œdata generation, density estimation, learning reusable embeddings and fine-tuningâ€, consequently claiming that TabPFN is a tabular foundation model.888These capabilities were not fully investigated by Hollmann etÂ al. [20] and some are not supported by their publicly available code at the time of writing. Our investigations support this claim by showing that simple applications of TabPFN can surpass state-of-the-art approaches to some statistical estimation problems.

These studies are of course preliminaryâ€”our numerical experiments made exclusive use of synthetic dataâ€”and we do not suggest that TabPFN is a perfect modelâ€”it seems to struggle with dense regression, cannot handle â‰¥500absent500\geq 500â‰¥ 500 features, and has MSE curves which seem to plateau for nâ‰¥10â¢Kğ‘›10ğ¾n\geq 10Kitalic_n â‰¥ 10 italic_K samples [27]. On the other hand, the evidence suggests that tabular foundation models are not only possible, but can surpass existing modeling approaches on a wide range of statistical tasks, possibly touching on all areas of statistics. In addition, VanÂ Breugel and Van DerÂ Schaar [39] have a bold vision of tabular foundational models being able to perform automatic meta-analyses, out-of-domain simulation, and other tasks for which adequate methodology does not yet exist. This line of thinkingâ€”that there may one day be one model to rule them allâ€”is of course contrary to mainstream statistical thinking, which has traditionally emphasized bespoke models for different problems. Just as AI scientists continue to wrestle with the academic and societal consequences of the emergence of foundation models, statisticians may also be forced to confront profound changes in our field.

5.2 In-context learning

Another way in which TabPFN challenges current statistical thinking is via its illustration of the power of â€œin-context learningâ€, whose historical development we now discuss. In a landmark paper, Brown etÂ al. [7] studied the LLM GPT-3 and discovered that it could learn how to perform tasks (e.g., language translation) that it was not explicitly trained to do and without changing any of the modelâ€™s parameters, simply by providing examples of the task in a prompt (text input) to the model. They called this ability â€œin-context learningâ€ (ICL). Garg etÂ al. [15] later framed ICL as a statistical learning problem. Under their framework, a prompt Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P is a random sequence (X1,fâ¢(X1),â€¦,Xn,fâ¢(Xn),Xn+1)subscriptğ‘‹1ğ‘“subscriptğ‘‹1â€¦subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›ğ‘“subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›1(X_{1},f(X_{1}),\ldots,X_{n},f(X_{n}),X_{n+1})( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_f ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , â€¦ , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_f ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), where X1,â€¦,Xn+1subscriptğ‘‹1â€¦subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›1X_{1},\ldots,X_{n+1}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are drawn IID from a covariate distribution DXsubscriptğ·ğ‘‹D_{X}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and fğ‘“fitalic_f is drawn from a distribution Dfsubscriptğ·ğ‘“D_{f}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over a function class â„±â„±{\mathcal{F}}caligraphic_F. A model Mğ‘€Mitalic_M is a fixed mapping from prompts to the (real-valued) label space and is said to have learned â„±â„±{\mathcal{F}}caligraphic_F in-context (with respect to (DX,Df)subscriptğ·ğ‘‹subscriptğ·ğ‘“(D_{X},D_{f})( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )) if ğ”¼Pâ¢[lâ¢(Mâ¢(P),fâ¢(Xn+1))]â‰¤Ïµsubscriptğ”¼ğ‘ƒdelimited-[]ğ‘™ğ‘€ğ‘ƒğ‘“subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›1italic-Ïµ{\mathbb{E}}_{P}[l(M(P),f(X_{n+1}))]\leq\epsilonblackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_l ( italic_M ( italic_P ) , italic_f ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) ] â‰¤ italic_Ïµ for some tolerance Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ and loss function lğ‘™litalic_l. Garg etÂ al. [15] was able to show via numerical experiments that a transformer, trained from scratch on IID prompts generated as described above, could successfully learn simple function classes (e.g. linear functions) in-context, inspiring a wave of theoretical interest in the problem [44, 4, 23].

On the other hand, it seems that Brown etÂ al. [7] and Garg etÂ al. [15]â€™s definitions of ICL are respectively too broad and too narrow to capture the scope of the learning strategy employed by TabPFN and other recent work claiming to implement ICL to solve statistical estimation problems. These include causal discoveryÂ [12], posterior inference for generalized linear models, factor models, and Gaussian mixture modelsÂ [34], RNA folding time density estimationÂ [36], and Poisson mean estimation under empirical BayesÂ [38]. None of these works provide a definition of ICL, but we find that the common denominator is that they train a transformer model using a large number of synthetic datasets to learn a mapping on the space of datasets. The target of the mapping can be a causal graph, a posterior distribution on parameter vector, or a Poisson mean vector estimate. In each of these problems, the ICL approach is shown to achieve higher accuracy than state-of-the-art methods, such as variational inference for posterior approximation, or non-parametric maximum-likelihood estimation in the case of empirical Bayes.

5.3 Future directions

These advances present both opportunities and challenges for the statistical community. TabPFNâ€™s success stems from a synthesis of ideas across disciplines, coupled with non-trivial engineering efforts. The current versionÂ [20] builds on its predecessorÂ [19], with key improvements in (1) prior data generation and (2) transformer architectureâ€”both empirically shown to enhance performance. As statisticians, we can contribute to this evolving field by addressing critical questions:

  • â€¢

    Interpretability & theoretical foundations: Transformers, with millions of parameters, often lack interpretability. Understanding when TabPFN succeeds or failsâ€”along with its statistical guaranteesâ€”remains an open problem.

  • â€¢

    Reliability in practice: While TabPFN and related methods show promise as off-the-shelf tools for biomedical and other applications, their real-world reliabilityâ€”particularly for inference tasksâ€”requires rigorous evaluation.

  • â€¢

    Scalability & limitations: Current implementations struggle with dense/high-dimensional regression and <10absent10<10< 10K samples. Addressing this bottleneck is essential for broader applicability. Recent work likeÂ [33] offers preliminary solutions, but fundamental constraints remain.

D.2 Gaussian process regression

For both 1D and 2D cases, we compare TabPFN with Gaussian process regression (GPR). For Gaussian process regression, we consider 5555 kernels: constant kernel Ã—\timesÃ— RBF kernel, constant kernel Ã—\timesÃ— Matern kernel, constant kernel Ã—\timesÃ— RationalQuadratic kernel, constant kernel Ã—\timesÃ— ExpSineSquared kernel, constant kernel Ã—\timesÃ— RBF kernel +++ constant kernel Ã—\timesÃ— Matern kernel. The candidate variance Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2}italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of the measurement error is over the grid [0.05,0.1,0.15,0.2]0.050.10.150.2[0.05,0.1,0.15,0.2][ 0.05 , 0.1 , 0.15 , 0.2 ]. We maximize the marginal log-likelihood to select the optimal kernel and its corresponding optimal parameters, and the optimal measurement error variance. The optimal parameter for GPR is implemented using the GaussianProcessRegressor in sklearn package in Python.
